awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Resonant Sensors for Wireless Monitoring of Viable Cell Concentration in Small, Disposable Bioreactors
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to develop a resonant sensor system to monitor cell viability in small bioreactors.  Cell factories are responsible for producing more than $150B worth of cell therapies, protein therapies, industrial enzymes, and small molecules each year.  At the development phase, there are few technologies to monitor viable cell concentration, a critical quality attribute in a large array of bioreactors.  Current methods to monitor cell viability are labor intensive, expensive, and can compromise quality.  The proposed technology could be embedded into the walls of disposable flasks and bioreactors to provide real-time measurement of viable cell concentration.  This could enable substantial "big data" improvements for bioprocess developers, clonal selection, and small batch production.

This STTR Phase I project proposes to demonstrate passive, wireless sensing of viable cell concentration with resonant sensors.  Dielectric probes are used in industry to correlate culture capacitance to viable cell concentration in large culture volumes. In this proposal, the change in culture capacitance in small culture volumes could be wireless reported with a passive sensor embedded as part of the disposable culture flask or single-use bioreactor.  In this form factor, it would never make contact with the cell product, would be wirelessly implemented, and would have potential to be easily multiplexed.  Technical objectives for this work are 1) determining the extent of confounding signal effects from movement, media composition and temperature; 2) building a Bluetooth enabled reader pad for implementation in an incubator; and 3) developing an algorithm that translates the complex resonant sensor amplitude and phase data into simple parameters that can be used to track viable cell concentration.  In addition, the plan is to model and test the effect of resonator geometry, material composition, and sensor placement.  The goal is to produce a robust sensor system for cell viability to test in real culture conditions on numerous cell types.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Skroot Laboratory, Inc. aspires to build tools for cell-based manufacturing that enables faster routes to better quality product. In particular, the NSF funding was for development of our first product, a wireless monitor to noninvasively follow cell growth in bioreactors for upstream biotherapeutic process developers to enable them to make rigorous models, reduce risk of progressing costly conditions/products, and reduce time to market. Additionally, the same wireless sensor system can be used by single use bioreactor manufacturers to provide a unique feature for their end customers and increase their market share.

During Phase I, the feasibility of continuous, non-invasive cell growth monitoring for fermentation research and development has been demonstrated and early prototype equipment assembled for on-site testing to extend applications beyond what we have demonstrated in our lab. Numerous discussions with those working with bioreactors noted the advantages of having continuous monitoring for developing their models and catching the optimal times to take feed and harvest actions for their reactors.

Figure 1 illustrates the progression of steps as executed in a laboratory incubator-shaker with small cell growth flasks.  Sensor stickers are affixed to the vessel, which is then placed close to the reader, resonance frequency shifts reflecting cell growth are obtained from the monitor via programming in a small single-board computer and the results can be displayed and plotted as cell concentration vs time with high frequency of measurement. Figure 2 shows the impact of vessel contents on resonant frequency when consecutive signals are obtained with air and water in the vessel. Figure 3 shows a prototype cell growth monitor packaged for delivery to collaborating test site, while Figure 4 shows that monitor affixed to a pilot-scale, single-use cell growth vessel.

Development of the sensor stickers, reader antennas, relative placement of sensor and reader was guided by a combination of experiment and numerical simulation of the system.  The algorithm to extract growth curves was written in Python, run on a single-board computer that controls the sampling rate and frequency range scanned and also provides the user interface.

Broader Impacts:

We are developing multiple skills in our young technical staff at the interface of instrumentation and fermentation. These include sensor/reader simulations, device and programming development, device fabrication methods, and cell growth in a variety of bioreactors.

Commercial versions of our cell monitoring device ? the subject of our Phase II proposal - will enable more rapid and less costly development of fermentation processes for biopharmaceuticals/cell therapy resulting in lower cost medical care.

 


Last Modified: 03/05/2020
Modified by: Charles E Glatz
